questions.neutral: Feel like a slow night to you?

hobby.message: You still tuning those antique typewriters?
That camera still your favorite weapon?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Slow, yes. Routine disrupted lately.
I mostly keep to myself, restoring things. Typewriters, mainly.
Not a popular pastime these days.
Recent events have made even quiet hobbies complicated.
Feels different. City’s pace flipped on its head.
I restore antique typewriters, for the patience it teaches.
Was easier before score changes caught up with the neighborhood.
Even finding quiet for it’s a task now.
Seems nothing simple stays simple.
Slow night, but not quiet. Building’s full of unfamiliar footsteps now.
I spend time with antique typewriters—restoring, cleaning, sometimes writing notes.
Since the score reversals, even my hobby’s changed.
Noticed someone else using one nearby—unusual, likely not coincidence.
Strange how chaos brings old habits to the surface again.
Suppose some of us hold onto what we can.
City’s turned itself inside out lately. Quiet, but nothing feels settled.
I’ve been restoring typewriters for years. Mechanical, tangible—calms the nerves.
Usually write by hand too, but old keys feel right.
Other night, heard someone else typing. Never noticed before.
Wonder if more folks are reaching for something untraceable.
My own access was pulled, less distraction for awhile.
Changes make small things oddly meaningful.
Feels slow, but there’s tension under it. Hard to ignore now.
Old habits keep me steady—I restore typewriters, write journals. Used to be normal.
Years ago, before all the BCI noise, these machines were just nostalgia.
Since that score-flip, everything’s upended. My score dropped, lost access, lost quiet corners too.
Funny—could hear someone else on a typewriter, first time in years.
Guess we’re seeking ways to speak privately. Unrecorded, unwatched.
Lately, fixing ribbon or cleaning keys takes on new importance.
It’s grounding—being needed by something the system can’t read or rewire.
hobby_answer: They are, for the most part. Reliable, at least.
Nothing like the city’s current noise to make you value old machines.
Recent days, typewriters attract more attention than usual. Sometimes unwanted.
People start listening for things not meant to be overheard.
I keep my notes brief, when I bother at all.
Better than most people, especially lately.
Mechanical honesty, no background monitoring or score recalculations.
Since the flip, every keystroke echoes through half the block.
You never know who’s listening, now that positions have swapped.
Letters sound different than data leaks, but reach strange ears just the same.
I keep my repairs quiet these days.
Honestly, yes. Typewriters have never betrayed anyone’s trust.
Every key has its place, quite unlike this city nowadays.
Score-flip shook up more than routines — it made every noise suspicious.
Typing used to be background hum. Now it draws curiosity from old and new neighbors.
Funny, how analog habits carry risks in a digital mess.
I keep mechanicals running, but watchful for who might notice.
It’s not just nostalgia, you see.
They do. More loyal than the BCI, at any rate.
Restored four machines last year, but only use two now.
After the score reversal, suddenly people hear what you’re writing — literally.
Someone else picked up an old Olympia below my floor. I recognize the rhythm.
All this system upheaval, and the old tools become signals of defiance.
I once helped a Council member recover his father’s Underwood. He would understand this solace.
Some find comfort in broadcast; I find it in ribbon and platen.
Even analog ink stains draw looks these days.
Absolutely. Typewriters still keep secrets better than people or any archive.
Started fixing them as a child — father’s was a Czech Diplomat model.
The recent score chaos? Turned every keystroke into a confession. Anyone listening, anyone recording.
Neighbors now trade glances at the Remington’s click, sizing up loyalty or dissent.
Restored a carbon copy machine last winter, but it’s too loud now — gave it to a friend gone ‘quiet’.
I keep spare ribbons hidden, just in case they get rationed next.
After Halden’s protocols triggered, even the simple act of typing felt charged.
Some nights I type out messages for old friends, never to send.
Machines age, but their honesty embarrasses the city’s new order.
